awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator: Track H: Restoring Arm Function with Connected Assistance and Rehabilitation Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, Convergence Accelerator Track H: Restoring Arm Function After Stroke (RAFAS) will develop and translate a cloud-connected, soft, wearable rehabilitation and assistance platform to restore arm function and independence for stroke survivors, veterans, and others with upper limb disability. At the heart of the development process are stroke survivors, caregivers, occupational therapists, physical therapists, neurologists, and clinicians. The vision of restoring arm function after stroke through new wearable technology is well beyond the scope of a single-investigator proposal. These communities are engaged via focus groups, development testing, formal protocols, and clinical feasibility testing to maximize the translation potential of this technology. RAFAS will enable a paradigm shift from the current ‘in clinic’ model of rehabilitation to one of remote physical rehabilitation for persons with upper limb disability. RAFAS’ broadening participation goal is to attract, train and mentor the next generation of rehabilitation and assistive technology innovators focused on use-inspired research while accelerating knowledge integration and communication across traditional boundaries. Primary attention will be placed on students and faculty who identify as racial/ethnic minorities, or are female, veterans or persons with disabilities. RAFAS engages PWDs via a Patient Advisory Board, a research webinar series, and workshops and panels that bring together engineering students with persons with disabilities to discuss challenges and opportunities for technology development. RAFAS supports hackathons, with industry panels focused on bringing assistive technology to market and undergraduate and graduate students via research experiences and mentoring. Finally, outreach events targeted to female high school students and focused on occupational therapy will encourage broader participation in the fields of assistive and rehabilitation technology. 

The primary Phase I deliverables are: a minimal viable prototype of a wearable, adaptive antigravity support to the upper limb that can be used in the home; estimation and control algorithms using wearable sensors for remote assessment and individualized assistance; a software app enabling independent use by patients and therapists and a gap analysis to determine research and development goals in Phase II to enable eventual translation. Phase II work will entail optimizing the technology based on feedback from stakeholders and at-home pilots in Phase I and running a larger remote telerehabilitation study to generate evidence of improved outcomes and enable integration of remote rehabilitation into the new insurance landscape. RAFAS brings to this effort a combination of skills and expertise spanning: (1) the ability to create lightweight and flexible soft wearable robots that can apply significant assistance without adding restrictions; (2) the understanding of how to extract important clinic metrics from noisy, raw wearable sensor data; (3) the foundational knowledge of rehabilitation science and the most effective arm movements to encourage and support occupational therapy/physical therapy; and (4) the capability to establish an integrated experimental framework with human subjects to guide ongoing technical development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing initial enabling technology for a cloud-connected soft wearable rehabilitation and assistance platform to restore arm function and independence for stroke survivors, veterans, and others with upper limb disability. Upper limb disability impacts over 10 million people in the United States (US) and of the almost one million people in the US who experience stroke annually, an estimated 75% have long-term challenges using their affected arm. While the optimal dose of therapy is not known, repetitions on the order of hundreds per day are likely necessary to maximize recovery. Patients frequently lack the capacity to practice high quality and high-volume functional movements, leading to a negative cycle of upper limb disuse and further degradation of ability, with impacts to the patient's independence, ability to work, and quality of life. This project brought together expertise in: (i) soft robotics, wearable robotics, functional apparel, computer science, machine learning, biomechanics, healthcare; (ii) rehabilitation sciences, neurology, physical therapy, occupational therapy; and (iii) telehealth, rehabilitation, product development, and commercialization. The research was guided by end users, stakeholders, and advocates including stroke survivors and occupational therapy educators. In total, the project engaged with 36 end-users and stakeholders through interviews, focus groups, in-lab and at-home evaluations. As a direct result, the project uncovered the limitations of an initial prototype of a soft wearable robot. This led to the co-creation of physical and software low fidelity prototypes to make the design widely usable and advance a standalone digital therapeutic, both that were well-received by end-users. Participation in NSF's Convergence Accelerator Phase 1 curriculum enabled important modifications to the project path and approach.

Intellectual Merit: The project collected three-dimensional motion capture data in a laboratory environment for 10 stroke survivors to gain insights on approaches to quantify upper extremity movement quality. This led to evaluation of the technology with 20 stroke survivors and 9 therapists through weekly testing over an 8-month period. Through customer discovery, the team learned stroke survivors have a strong desire to use the developed technology independently. In a pilot user study on 10 stroke survivors wearing the soft wearable robot prototype and performing simulated ADLs, there were improvements in biomechanical metrics such as range of motion and maximum reaching distance. The project also focused on the development of methods that enable automatic assessment of recovery and personalized control. Phase I deliverables were (1) a minimal viable prototype of a wearable, adaptive antigravity support to the upper limb, (2) estimation and control approaches that enable remote assessment of upper extremity movement and adaptive and individualized assistance (3) a plan for further research and development goals to enable eventual translation.

Broader Impacts: The technology will enable a paradigm shift from the current in clinic model of rehabilitation to one where it can be performed from the home. Through a combination of assistance and rehabilitation it will restore arm function for the millions of stroke survivors and longer term also provide assistance to other populations with upper extremity disability such as individuals with spinal cord injury, ALS and muscular dystrophy. This project grew partnerships with the stroke survivor community and other rehabilitation centers within and outside of the Greater Boston area. This project also facilitated discussion and collaboration between engineering students and persons with disabilities, to bring people together to discuss challenges and opportunities for technology development. Outreach events for occupational therapy and female high school students were also run to encourage broader participation in the fields of assistive and rehabilitation technology.
